awd_titl_txt: Rethinking Dredging:  Phasing Small Dam Deconstruction to Allow Sediment Releases without Harming Downstream Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
0967918
Curran

The objective of the proposed research is to determine the downstream morphologic impacts caused by different combinations of small dam deconstruction sequencing and impounded reservoir sediment characteristics.  The central hypothesis is that for a given distribution of impounded sediments, small dam deconstruction can be sequenced such that impounded sediments released downstream increase the available habitat created by the channel morphology and thereby improve the downstream ecosystem.  A series of laboratory flume experiments will measure sediment transport rates and changes to the downstream channel bed under various combinations of sediment mixtures and small dam deconstruction phasing sequences for each of several scaled dam sizes.  Geomorphic variability in the downstream channel will be measured after each phase of dam deconstruction, and data analysis will result in a series of qualitative and quantitative descriptions of small dam removals under a range of conditions.

por.por_cntn:
Dam removal is an increasingly common practice but is complicated by questions concerning the impounded sediment. Two of the most common questions concerning a dam removal focus on the volume of impounded sediment that will be eroded and the amount that will be deposited or eroded from the downstream channel. The objective of the proposed research was to determine the downstream morphologic impacts caused by different combinations of dam deconstruction sequencing and impounded reservoir sediment characteristics. The central hypothesis stated that for a given distribution of impounded sediments, dam deconstruction can be sequenced such that impounded sediments released downstream increase the available habitat created by the channel morphology and thereby improve the downstream ecosystem.

Five common methods of dam deconstruction were identified and tested in a scaled physical model. These were removal in horizontal layers from the top; removal in horizontal notches with the sides of the dam left in place; removal in vertical pieces from the side; removal in vertical pieces from the center; removal in a single-step, which also simulated a dam failure, Each removal method was tested under low flow and flood conditions and with three different sediment mixtures which were chosen to represent a broad range of physiographic regions. The finest sediment mixture included a large amount of silt while the coarsest had no sediment smaller than 2 mm. The experiments applied geometric and dynamic scaling ratios derived from documented dam removals to measured dam removals to enable broad application of the results to dams across the US.

There were 25 experiments completed with each experiment consisting of a full dam deconstruction. The experiments varied in length by the number of dam pieces in each removal method. After each segment of a flume experiment, the bed surface scanned and a pebble count conducted using the color of the grain to indicate grain size fraction. Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) of each bed surface were created from the bed surface laser scans and by differencing these DEMS, areas of preferential deposition and erosion downstream of the dam removal were identified. Volumes of erosion and deposition were measured after each dam removal stage as well as changes in bed surface topographic variability. The flume enabled measurements over 10 channel widths downstream of the dam removal. The amount of sediment that transported out of the flume represents the amount transported completely through the downstream channel reach. Together these data provided a means of measuring the effect of different dam removal methods and evaluating the central research hypothesis.

Each dam removal method generated a different channel response. Therefore the analyses to date have focused on how flow rate and sediment mixture affected changes in the channel with dam removal. During high flows, dam removal resulted in a bed that remained topographically consistent for the horizontal and notched removal methods but experienced erosion when the dam was removed in a single step. In contrast, vertical removal methods led to aggradation of the downstream channel bed despite the high flow rates. Reservoir erosion was greater under high flow rates for the vertical-side and notched dam removals indicating that much of the sediment eroded from the impoundment deposited within the first 10 channel widths downstream of the dam. For low flow removals, downstream bed topography remained most consistent when removal followed a horizontal or notched sequence and there was net aggradation of the downstream channel following vertical removals.
